00049 /** 
00050  * Make a string from an integer.
00051  * @param i - integer to be converted.
00052  * 
00053  * @return - String version of int i;
00054  */
00055 string Convert::toString(int i) {
00056   stringstream ss;
00057   string str;
00058   ss << i;
00059   ss >> str;
00060   return str;
00061 }
00062 
00063 /** 
00064  * Make a string from an double
00065  * @param d - double to be converted.
00066  * 
00067  * @return - String version of int i;
00068  */
00069 std::string Convert::toString(double d) {
00070   stringstream ss;
00071   string str;
00072   ss << d;
00073   ss >> str;
00074 
00075   // we prefer the linux format (inf/nan) to that of the windows output.
00076   // convert the strings to our perfered format.
00077   if (str == "-Inf") {
00078     str = "-inf";
00079   }
00080   else if (str == "Inf") {
00081     str = "inf";
00082   }
00083 #ifdef WIN32
00084   else if (str.size() >= 5) {
00085     if (str == "-1.#INF") {
00086       str="-inf";
00087     } 
00088     else if (str == "1.#INF") {
00089       str="inf";
00090     }
00091     else if (str == "-1.#IND") {
00092       str="nan";
00093     }
00094     else if (str == "1.#IND") {
00095       str="nan";
00096     }
00097     // For Windows, check to see if a three digit exponent with a leading zero
00098     // is being used for double representation.  if so, remove the extra zero
00099     // (2 exponent digits conforms to 1999 C standard) 
00100     // e.g. 1.234e003 and 1.234e-003 become 1.234e03 and 1.234e-03
00101     else if (str.at(str.size() - 3) == '0' &&
00102              (str.at(str.size() - 4) == 'e' || 
00103               str.at(str.size() - 5) == 'e')
00104              ) {
00105       str.erase(str.size() - 3, 1);
00106     }
00107   }
00108 #endif
00109   return str;
00110 }

00112 /** 
00113  * Make an int from a c string or die trying.
00114  * @param num - c string representation of number to be parsed.
00115  * 
00116  * @return - Integer representation of num
00117  */
00118 int Convert::toInt(const std::string& num) {
00119   bool success = true;
00120   int i = Convert::toIntCheck(num, &success);
00121   if(success != true)
00122     Err::errAbort("Could not convert '" + std::string(num) + "' to an int.");
00123   return i;
00124 }
00125 
00126 /** 
00127  * Make an int from a c string.
00128  * @param num - c string representation of number to be parsed.
00129  * @param success - If success != NULL set to true upon 
00130  *   successful conversion and false upon failur.
00131  * @return - Integer representation of num, 0 if success == false
00132  */
00133 int Convert::toIntCheck(const std::string& num, bool *success) {
00134   long int l = 0;
00135   int i = 0;
00136   bool ok = true;
00137   char *end = NULL;
00138   const char* num_c_str=num.c_str();
00139 
00140   assert(num_c_str); 
00141   errno = 0;
00142   l = strtol(num_c_str, &end, 10);
00143 
00144   // end will be NULL if entire string converted.
00145   ok = (*end != '\0' || end == num_c_str) ? false : true;
00146   
00147   // cast to int and make sure that we didn't overflow
00148   i = (int)l;
00149   if(errno != 0 || (long)i != l)
00150     ok = false;
00151 
00152   // if we had a problem set to 0 for consistency.
00153   if(!ok)
00154     i = 0;
00155 
00156   if(success != NULL)
00157     (*success) = ok;
00158 
00159   return i;
00160 }
00161

00163  * Make an uint from a c string or die trying.
00164  * @param num - c string representation of number to be parsed.
00165  * 
00166  * @return - Unsigned Integer representation of num
00167  */
00168 unsigned int Convert::toUnsignedInt(const std::string& num) {
00169   bool success = true;
00170   unsigned int i = Convert::toUnsignedIntCheck(num, &success);
00171   if(success != true)
00172     Err::errAbort("Could not convert '" + std::string(num) + "' to an unsigned int.");
00173   return i;
00174 }

00184 /** 
00185  * Make an unsigned int from a c string.
00186  * @param num - c string representation of number to be parsed.
00187  * @param success - If success != NULL set to true upon 
00188  *   successful conversion and false upon failur.
00189  * @return - Unsigned Integer representation of num, 0 if success == false
00190  */
00191 unsigned int Convert::toUnsignedIntCheck(const std::string& num, bool *success) {
00192   long unsigned int l = 0;
00193   unsigned int i = 0;
00194   bool ok = true;
00195   char *end = NULL;
00196   const char* num_c_str=num.c_str();
00197 
00198   assert(num_c_str); 
00199   errno = 0;
00200   l = strtoul(num_c_str, &end, 10);
00201 
00202   // end will be NULL if entire string converted.
00203   ok = (*end != '\0' || end == num_c_str) ? false : true;
00204 
00205   // cast to unsigned int and make sure that we didn't overflow
00206   i = (unsigned int)l;
00207   if(errno != 0 || (long unsigned int)i != l || l >= UINT_MAX) 
00208     ok = false;
00209 
00210   // if we had a problem set to 0 for consistency.
00211   if(!ok)
00212     i = 0;
00213 
00214   if(success != NULL)
00215     (*success) = ok;
00216 
00217   return i;
00218 }

00220 uint64_t Convert::toUnsignedInt64Check(const std::string& num, bool *success) {
00221   long unsigned int l = 0;
00222   uint64_t i = 0;
00223   bool ok = true;
00224   char *end = NULL;
00225   const char* num_c_str=num.c_str();
00226 
00227   assert(num_c_str); 
00228   errno = 0;
00229   l = strtoul(num_c_str, &end, 10);
00230 
00231   // end will be NULL if entire string converted.
00232   ok = (*end != '\0' || end == num_c_str) ? false : true;
00233 
00234   // cast to unsigned int and make sure that we didn't overflow
00235   i = (uint64_t)l;
00236   if(errno != 0 || (long unsigned int)i != l || l >= ULONG_MAX) 
00237     ok = false;
00238 
00239   // if we had a problem set to 0 for consistency.
00240   if(!ok)
00241     i = 0;
00242 
00243   if(success != NULL)
00244     (*success) = ok;
00245 
00246   return i;
00247 }

00249 /** 
00250  * Make an float from a c string.
00251  * @param num - c string representation of number to be parsed.
00252  * 
00253  * @return - Float representation of num
00254  */
00255 float Convert::toFloat(const std::string& num) {
00256   bool success = true;
00257   float f = toFloatCheck(num, &success);
00258   if(!success) 
00259     Err::errAbort("Could not convert '" + std::string(num) + "' to a float.");
00260   return f;
00261 }
00262 
00263 /** 
00264  * Make an float from a c string.
00265  * @param num - c string representation of number to be parsed.
00266  * @param success - If success != NULL set to true upon 
00267  *   successful conversion and false upon failur.
00268  * @return - Float representation of num
00269  */
00270 float Convert::toFloatCheck(const std::string& num, bool *success) {
00271   double d = toDoubleCheck(num, success);
00272   if(d > FLT_MAX && d < DBL_MAX) {
00273     (*success) = false;
00274   }
00275   return float(d);
00276 }

00280  * @param num - c string representation of number to be parsed.
00281  * 
00282  * @return - Double representation of num
00283  */
00284 double Convert::toDouble(const std::string& num){
00285   bool success = true;
00286   double d = Convert::toDoubleCheck(num, &success);
00287 
00288   if(!success)
00289     Err::errAbort("Could not convert '" + std::string(num) + "' to a double.");
00290 
00291   return d;
00292 }
00293 
00294 /** 
00295  * Make an double from a c string.
00296  * @param num - c string representation of number to be parsed.
00297  * @param success - If success != NULL set to true upon 
00298  *   successful conversion and false upon failur.
00299  * @return - Double representation of num
00300  */
00301 double Convert::toDoubleCheck(const std::string& num, bool *success){
00302   const char* num_c_str=num.c_str();
00303   assert(num_c_str);
00304 
00305   double d = 0;
00306 
00307   if (num == "NaN") {
00308       d = numeric_limits<double>::quiet_NaN();
00309       *success = true;
00310       return d;
00311   }
00312 
00313   char *end = NULL;
00314   bool ok = true;
00315   errno = 0;
00316   d = strtod(num_c_str, &end);
00317 
00318   // end will point at NULL if conversion successful
00319   ok = (*end != '\0' || end == num_c_str) ? false : true;
00320 
00321   /* errno should be set if over/under flow. ERANGE is a special case
00322      though of number not being represetable. For ERANGE just let things
00323      be with a warning...
00324 
00325      from https://www.securecoding.cert.org:
00326      "For numeric conversion functions in the strtod(), strtol(),
00327      wcstod(), and wcstol() families, if the correct result is outside
00328      the range of representable values, an appropriate minimum or
00329      maximum value is returned, and the value ERANGE is stored in
00330      errno.  For floating-point conversion functions in the strtod()
00331      and wcstod() families, if an underflow occurs, whether errno
00332      acquires the value ERANGE is implementation-defined."
00333   */
00334 
00335   if (errno != 0 && errno != ERANGE) {
00336     ok = false;
00337   }
00338 
00339   if (errno == ERANGE) {
00340     Verbose::out(3, "Warning - number: " + num + " is out of range (ERANGE set)");
00341     errno = 0;
00342   }
00343   /* If not ok set to NAN to be non-usable. */
00344   if (!ok) {
00345     d = 0.0;
00346     // @todo - check that NAN won't break everything...
00347     // d = NAN;
00348   }
00349   if(success != NULL)
00350     (*success) = ok;
00351 
00352   return d;
00353 }

00355 /** 
00356  * Make an bool from a c string.
00357  * @param flag - c string representation of number to be parsed.
00358  *    allowed value are 'true' && 'false'
00359  * @return - Bool representation of flag
00360  */
00361 bool Convert::toBool(const std::string& flag) {
00362   bool value = false, success = false;
00363   value = Convert::toBoolCheck(flag, &success);
00364   if(!success)
00365     Err::errAbort("Could not convert '" + std::string(flag) + "' to a boolean.\n"
00366                   "Valid values are: 'true','false','1','0'.");
00367   return value;
00368 }
00369 
00370 /** 
00371  * Make an bool from a c string.
00372  * @param flag - c string representation of number to be parsed.
00373  *   allowed value are 'true' && 'false'
00374  * @param success - If success != NULL set to true upon 
00375  *   successful conversion and false upon failur.
00376  * @return - Bool representation of flag, false on failure.
00377  */
00378 bool Convert::toBoolCheck(const std::string& flag, bool *success) {
00379   bool value = false;
00380   bool ok = true;
00381   const char* flag_c_str=flag.c_str();
00382 
00383   assert(flag_c_str);
00384 
00385   // would like to use strcasecmp, but VC++ doesnt have it
00386   if ((strcmp(flag_c_str, "true") == 0) ||
00387       (strcmp(flag_c_str, "TRUE") == 0) ||
00388       (strcmp(flag_c_str, "1")    == 0)) {
00389     value = true;
00390   }
00391   else if ((strcmp(flag_c_str, "false") == 0) ||
00392            (strcmp(flag_c_str, "FALSE") == 0) ||
00393            (strcmp(flag_c_str, "0") == 0)) {
00394     value = false;
00395   }
00396   else 
00397     ok = false;
00398 
00399   if(success != NULL)
00400     (*success) = ok;
00401 
00402   return value;
00403 }
00404 
00405 /** 
00406  * Test to make sure that two doubles are pretty similar.
00407  * @param f1 
00408  * @param f2 
00409  * @return true if doubles are same to 6 significant digits.
00410  */
00411 bool Convert::doubleCloseEnough(double d1, double d2, int digits) {
00412   double diff = fabs(d1 - d2);
00413   if(diff < 1 / (pow(10.0, (double)digits)))
00414     return true;
00415   return false;
00416 }
00417 
00418 /** 
00419  * Make a low precision float from a normal one. Used originally to
00420  * mimic truncation seen in cel files.
00421  * @param f float to be truncated.
00422  * @return truncated float
00423  */
00424 float Convert::floatLowPrecision(float f) {
00425   return (float)((floor((f+0.05)*10))/10.0);
00426 }

00428 void
00429 Convert::strToIntVec(const std::string& s,const char delim,std::vector<int>& vec)
00430 {
00431   std::vector<string> words;
00432   Util::chopString(s,delim, words);
00433   vec.clear();
00434   vec.resize(words.size());
00435   for(size_t i = 0; i < words.size(); i++) {
00436     vec[i] = Convert::toInt(words[i]);
00437   }
00438 }

00441 Convert::strToDoubleVec(const std::string& s, const char delim, std::vector<double>& vec)
00442 {

00444   Util::chopString(s, delim, words);
00445   vec.clear();
00446   vec.resize(words.size());
00447   for(int i = 0; i < words.size(); i++) {
00448     vec[i] = Convert::toDouble(words[i]);
00449   }
00450 }

00452 /**
00453  * Convert an integer vector to string
00454  */
00455 std::string Convert::intVecToString(const std::vector<int> &inputVector, const std::string &delim)
00456 {
00457     if (inputVector.empty()) {
00458         return "";
00459     }
00460 
00461     std::string str;
00462     for (std::vector<int>::const_iterator it = inputVector.begin(); it != inputVector.end(); ++it)
00463     {
00464         str += delim + toString(*it);
00465     }
00466     return str.substr(delim.size());
00467 }

00486 /**
00487  * Convert a string vector to string. Silly but someone's got to do it.
00488  */
00489 std::string Convert::strVecToString(const std::vector<std::string> &inputVector, const std::string &delim)
00490 {
00491     if (inputVector.empty()) {
00492         return "";
00493     }
00494 
00495     std::string str;
00496     for (std::vector<std::string>::const_iterator it = inputVector.begin(); it != inputVector.end(); ++it)
00497     {
00498         str += delim + *it;
00499     }
00500     return str.substr(delim.size());
